passages.text: One of the most notable drivers of power demand growth comes is datacentre load, a thematic tailwind and debate for the sector for more than a year. However, so far it has failed to materialise in higher growth ambitions across our coverage. We think capex upgrades for our coverage of pure players are still unlikely (value creation spreads are not improving and balance sheets are still looking constrained). We keep an overall cautious bias, with \(50\%\) of our coverage universe rated Underperform (we downgrade Acciona Energia to Underperform, see Lacking Energia Act II note).

Sentiment has improved for European renewables, after proving to be a painful trade for many investors over the past few years. Pure players have outperformed the sector by \(27pp+\) since US tariffs were announced. However, Acciona Energia and EDPR look quite expensive to us at \(10 - 12x\) by forward EBITDA relative to the sector and clean energy names on 8x. Shares have already moved ahead of revisions (consensus does not properly model growth), as has sentiment. Still, without clear upgrade on the outlook recent outperformance should unwind as execution and leverage headroom remain tight.

The worst- case scenario for US renewables has been averted, but value creation spreads in renewables has not expanded (capex not down, rates not down, PPAs not up). Better value on higher prices could materialise as power demand from datacentres may be underestimated but will attract capital and competition. Also, we still see balance sheets as quite stretched, which will likely constrain capex upgrades (we expect strategic reviews at EDP and Iberdrola to focus on networks).

We think the market is overpaying for Acciona Energia and EDPR assets, pipeline or underestimating liabilities. Too- high leverage and no clear improvement in industry fundamentals still constrain the growth profile, with a high reliance on asset rotations. Whilst a take- out by either parent Acciona or EDP is a risk (both management keep all options open), we believe it is unlikely following the recent share price recovery. We also remain bearish on Orsted with the upcoming equity raise a near- term overhang.

We continue to favour Greenergy as our top pick based on its excellent execution and potential for raised amplions (conservative guidance) that could drive the equity story further, as well as an attractive thematic backdrop in storage, increasingly more needed across Europe and beyond. We turn more positive on ERG (upgrade to Buy; see note: Dividend- mill) with growth ambitions more de- risked and a unique 'yieldco' proposition that investors should find attractive as European rates fall. We also think the risk- reward is binary for Solaria, with good expectations on datacentres priced in (downgrade to Neutral; see our Flying closer to the sun note).

See Appendix for a list of common abbreviations and acronyms

Sentiment has improved for renewables, but we caution not to get too carried away. We think capex upgrades for pure players are still unlikely (spreads not improving + execution on asset rotations still needed + balance sheets are still stretched) and that valuations, whilst rebased, are not particularly appealing.

We flag two Underperforms Acciona Energia (downgrade to Underperform) and EDPR as looking particularly expensive relative to other names we cover. ERG (upgrade to Buy) offers a lower execution risk and a 'yieldco' profile as rates fall. Greenergy remains our top pick on execution (and thematic) whilst we think Solaria (downgrade to Neutral) risk- reward is more binary as good expectations on renewables and datacentres are priced in. We remain bearish on Orsted given near- term overhang from the equity raise and execution, despite looking more fairly valued.

Short interest also remains higher than history across pure players but there are justifications. Acciona Energia and EDPR both have seen lower growth expectations from lower capacity deployed, and execution risks in asset rotations. In addition, Acciona Energia's lower liquidity and recent equity swaps could mean technical factors are at play. We are Underperform- rated on both Acciona Energia and EDPR. However, ERG's recent spike in short interest is less warranted, in our view, despite short- term downward pressure on EBITDA from poor wind performance (and lower exposure to the US, capacity additions or asset rotations). We are Buy- rated on ERG. In the case of Orsted, we highlight specific concerns on execution as well as a particular offshore risk in US renewables (see our Refinanced but not reassured note.
Source: BofA Global Research
Short interest across selected pure-play renewables (% free float) Source: BofA Global Research
Source: BofA Global Research

Renewables have likely been a painful trade for many investors over the past few years, and bearish political headlines from the US in 2024 and ear 2025 are renewable policies have not helped, given \(20 - 50\%\) of European developers operations and/or pipeline in that region. However, sentiment seems to have improved and a re- rating has begun since US tariffs were announced in April, and an averted worst- case- scenario of the full repeal of tax credits with the US tax bill in July. In addition, US power load growth continues to be bullish on Al/datacentres and reshoring ambitions, fuelling expectations for renewables (as power supply remains tight). Whilst we agree the US backdrop for renewables looks better (or at least, not incrementally worse), we would still caution against too much excitement, as we think capex upgrades for our European renewable coverage are unlikely, given execution risks and constrained balance sheets.

President Trump signed the new US tax bill on 4 July, which averted a worst- case (full repeal) scenario for tax credits (and therefore renewable developments). Legislation now gives enough to support renewable projects into 2030 (beyond the current presidential term, with the next US elections in 2028) and whilst President Trump signed an Executive Order on 7 July that questioned safe harbor rules, clarity from the US Treasury has now been given and mean developers should not bear too much cost increase to secure pipeline. The unresolved Foreign Entity of Concern rules are now the biggest source of uncertainty, especially for storage.

Exhibit 3: European renewables' recent performance has depended on US policy, recent dip as Orsted shaved off \(30\% +\) of its capitalisation following an announced - 68bn equity raise European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index performance (100 = 1 Jan 2024)
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg Note: European renewables as market-cap weighted average of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Grenergy, Orsted, Solaria. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Our US colleagues forecast \(2 - 2.5\%\) growth in power demand for the next decade (see their notes: US power demand growth and US power supply growth report). This contrasts with history, given electricity demand growth has been almost non- existent in the US over the past 10 years. Recent US capacity auctions (see their report: PJM auction) also highlight constrained supply, whilst PPA levels continue to tick up (see our report: Q2 PPA). Load growth has historically been overestimated (flat to declining

despite wide electrification trends) but growth is expected to be stronger (on rushed tech investments) and electricity demand growth has reached \(4 - 5\%\) over the last two years, meaning upside to volumes or value for renewables capacity. Europe could also see benefits, with datacentres slowly moving in and European Utilities looking at around \(1 - 2\%\) demand growth compared to the slightly downward trend over the past 10 years.

Despite AI load growth expectations and more settled policy in the US, our work shows that value creation spreads has not increased for European developers, meaning limited support for incremental investments. We also think near- term improvements are too difficult to call (lower rates and forwards in Europe should pressure PPA prices with incremental pricing risks from more negative hours). Planned investments in renewables have seen no uptick over the past 12 months and are instead down for most pure players and larger integrated utilities. Better spreads are necessary and could materialise should PPA prices in the US (and in Europe) rise more significantly.
Exhibit 4: Monetization for European developers not improving
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, LevelTen
Exhibit 5: Overall spread compression for European developers
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, BNEF, LevelTen

Better load growth should - in isolation - support renewables, especially as natural gas (and nuclear) takes much longer to build. However, we also see that load growth is being captured by 'traditional' power sources, from nuclear deals (from the landmark 1GW Talen- Amazon² 2024 deal) to even bigger hydro deals (the 3GW Brookfield- Google³ 2025 deal) or dedicated power land with gas deals (190MW Calpine- CyrusOne⁴ 2025 deal). Also, private players (landmark 10.5GW Brookfield- Microsoft⁵ 2024 deal) are taking a big chunk of growth.
Better value creation and strong growth expectations should continue to attract capital and therefore competition, in our view.
This could arguably also support pipeline or asset rotations from 'smaller' pure players and, given pipeline size is usually a multiple of expected capacity additions, we also
cannot discount similar deals being signed by European renewable pure players and/or larger integrated firms in one form or another.
However, datacentres have increasingly needed speed, reliability and clean energy (in that order). Clean energy is coming as long as it does not come at the expense of speed and reliability.

We would also argue that larger integrated firms have preferred to allocate more capex into regulated networks, and committed capital with the regulator cannot switch back easily into renewables. We think the strategic updates from EDP and Iberdrola in late 2025 are unlikely to focus on more renewables, and instead on more networks, aligned with current trends across the European utility sector.

Leverage doubled from 2x on average in 2022 to 4x in 2024 (see Exhibit 6). We expect a significant drop in net capacity growth in the coming years, as gross ambitions have been revised down, whilst asset rotation programs have been maintained or raised, meaning leverage will step likely down to 3x in 2026 as net capacity growth slows. However, this leverage reduction is somehow conditioned by asset rotations.
We also note that economic liabilities are significant (see Exhibit 7), meaning a tight execution window over a longer horizon.
Exhibit 6: Leverage has doubled, but is now reducing Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA excluding capital gains
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 7: Underlying leverage 1-3x higher than reported IFRS leverage vs BofA economic adjustments (x)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA including capital gains Note: Economic net debt including mainly tax equity, PPE payables, provisions

With all the above in mind, we find it useful to explore the catch- 22 problem faced by renewables developers, where capital is spent upfront of EBITDA contributions. As we have analysed in our EDP/EDPR Hyperhydro Syndrome report, growth can accelerate and become more compelling - but credit ratings have very tight headroom, meaning execution needs to be near- perfect, with any delays or funding gap (from delays or lower tax equity funding or capex financing for instance) growing as the pipeline itself grows.
Bottom line, renewables developers had bigger ambitions even only a couple quarters ago (EDPR management had previous ambitions of \(>4GW\) per annum back in 2023, compared to \(

were raised as capacity ambitions were cut) and execution (over pipeline and asset rotations alike) with no margin for error or mishaps, given the parent's leverage limits upside risk from higher capex ambitions.

EV/EBITDA 2y forward multiples are now at 9x on average for our renewables coverage, compared to 8x for the utility sector and 8x for clean energy transition names, vs 9x, 7x and 7.5x respectively, in 2015- 19 which precedes the ESG 'bubble' (see Exhibit 8).

Whilst this looks reasonable to us, we continue to see disparities in valuations – with Acciona Energia and EDPR looking notably more expensive. We expand on valuation (absolute and relative) as well as on our recommendations in the next section.

Exhibit 8: Clean energy offers better growth than utilities, for the same multiple, but some pure- play renewables (Acciona Energia and EDPR) are looking relatively more expensive European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index 2y forward EV/EBITDA and CAGR (Bloomberg consensus)

Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg Note: We use 2025-27 CAGR for our coverage and indexes, except 2024-26 for SXXP (data errors) we restate Acciona Energia to remove 2025 hydro one-offs. Greenergy and Solaria are off charts as outliers given strong EBITDA growth.

Share price performance for renewables has inflected (EDPR have returned \(50\% +\) since April lows) but valuations have not fully recovered since the US elections. Whilst consensus does not fully model growth, we think shares have already moved ahead of positive revisions, and growth remains constrained. Headline valuations look more reasonable, but Acciona Energia and EDPR seem particularly expensive to us. Our overall stance continues to be cautious on our pure- play coverage, \(50\%\) of which we rate Underperform.
Better performance since tariffs were announced...

Shares for our coverage of European pure- play renewables have returned a median \(+23\%\) since the beginning of the year, an impressive performance compared to \(- 32\%\) in 2024 and \(- 6\%\) median on average across 2021, 2022 and 2023. Recent performance can largely be ascribed to changes in US policy: 1) 2024 declines ahead and after President Trump's election on 5 November 2024, and 2) 2025 increases from an averted worst- case scenario on US renewables (see Exhibit 9).

Exhibit 9: European renewables' recent performance has depended on US policy, recent dip as Orsted shaved off \(30\% +\) of its capitalisation following an announced - 68bn equity raise European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index total return (100 = 1 Jan 2024)
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg Note: European renewables as market-cap weighted average of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Greenergy, Orsted, Solaria. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

However, European renewables are still trading below levels seen ahead of last year's US elections on average. We also note contrasting performance and share price momentum across our coverage between 2024 and 2025, from a median \(- 32\%\) to \(20\%\) . However, Orsted is still declining, whilst EDPR and ERG performances have yet to see meaningful positive returns in 2025 (see Exhibit 10).
Exhibit 10: Inflection for renewables in 2025, but not for Orsted and minimal for EDPR and ERG European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index total performance, 2019-2025 ytd

Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg Note: European renewables as median of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Grenergy, Orsted, Solaria. Note: Axis has been fixed at \(-50\%\) and \(+100\%\) with outliers' values in Solaria and Grenergy in 2019, 2020 and 2024 BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

One source of conflict in our relative recommendations relates to consensus forecasts for Acciona Energia and EDPR. Indeed, we have Underperform ratings on both, despite our EBITDA forecasts being \(+9\%\) above consensus across 2026 and 2027.

However, we would caution against reading too much into consensus forecasts given the lack of granularity on underlying asset growth and accounting for capital gains. Our conversations with investors imply that some are using a very wide range of assumptions (low to high gross capacity, including or not asset rotations, including or not capital gains) and that revisions could be skewed by large modelling assumption changes, especially as we near closer to the forecasted year.

Indeed, whilst our forecasts are \(6\%\) above consensus on average for Acciona Energia and EDPR for 2026E and \(10\%\) for 2027E, they are \(- 5\%\) and \(+1\%\) respectively on average excluding capital gains (see Exhibit 11). This, despite net capacity additions \(- 24\%\) lower on average across 2026- 27E for Acciona Energia, and \(+35\%\) for EDPR (See Exhibit 12).

Note, however, a more restricted sample of estimates on capacity additions (5 for Acciona Energia, 8 for EDPR compared to 7 and 17 respectively at the EBITDA level on Visible Alpha) which makes readings between the two estimates quite difficult.
Exhibit 11: Our estimates are \(+9\%\) above consensus on average over 2026-27E but are \(-2\%\) below ex capital gains... Acciona Energia and EDPR EBITDA forecasts (€m) vs BBG
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg, Visible Alpha
Exhibit 12: We have different asset growth assumptions (24% over 2026-27E for ANE, \(+35\%\) for EDPR) and thus capital gain pool Acciona Energia and EDPR net capacity additions forecasts (MW) vs VA
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Visible Alpha

Whilst we are cognisant that higher forecasts should theoretically support share price performance (a risk to our Underperform ratings) we think they have been already reflected in recent share price performance, alongside the general improvement in sentiment for renewables. We also think the gap between the two should compress overall valuation, with higher numbers but much lower multiples.

Exhibit 13: EDPR shares have declined from €18 to €7 alongside earnings from €3.2bn to €2.1bn but have recovered to €10 despite stale earnings... EDPR EBITDA 2027 forecasts (€m) against share price, Sept '23 to Aug '25

Exhibit 14: ...as have ANE shares declined from €28 to €15 alongside earnings from €1.6bn to €1.25bn but have recovered to €24 despite stale earnings... ANE EBITDA 2027 forecasts (€m) against share price, Sept '23 to Aug '25

Leverage doubled from 2x on average in 2022 to 4x in 2024 (see Exhibit 16). We expect a significant drop in net capacity growth in the coming years, as gross ambitions have been revised down whilst asset rotation programs have been maintained or raised, meaning leverage will step down to 3x by 2026 as net capacity growth slows. We expect net capacity growth to drop from \(13\%\) on average in the past 5 years to \(5.5\%\) in the next 3 (see Exhibit 15).

However, this leverage reduction is somehow conditioned by asset rotations, meaning execution risks over 2 pipelines (gross additions + asset rotations). We would also note that economic liabilities are significant, meaning a tight execution window over a longer horizon.
Exhibit 15: Ambitions have been cut for renewable pure players Net GW capacity growth in renewables \((\%)\) 2020-27E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 16: Leverage has doubled, but now reducing Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA excluding capital gains 2022-27E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

Looking at valuation across the past 10 years, renewables (and wider clean energy transition) multiples have largely corrected since the enthusiasm of the 2020- 23 years, when ESG investment trends had pushed multiples to much higher levels. ESG investments are now de- emphasised (Morningstar reported record- high outflows in global ESG funds in Q1 2025, with the \(10^{\mathrm{th}}\) consecutive quarter of outflows in the US and Europe's first net outflow since 2018).

Rates have also, of course, affected multiples. US 10y yields are currently standing above \(4\%\) compared to \(1.5 - 3\%\) in 2015- 19 (they dropped to \(0.5\%\) in 2020 before coming back to \(4\%\) in 2023) but they have equally affected the wider Utility sector.

EV/EBITDA forward multiples are now at 9x on average for our renewables coverage compared to 8x for the utility sector and 8x for clean energy transition names, vs. 9x, 7x and 7.5x respectively across 2015- 19, and 12.5x, 8x and 11.5x during 2020- 23 (see Exhibit 17). Whilst this looks more reasonable to us compared to history, our coverage premium has started to gap up but we struggle to find evidence of material fundamental improvements across the sector, as we detail in this report.

Exhibit 17: Sentiment has improved but we caution against too much excitement like in 2020-23 European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index 2y forward EV/EBITDA. Aug 2015-Aug 2025
Source: Bloomberg consensus Note: European renewables as median of Acciona Energia, EDPR, ERG, Greenergy, Orsted, Solaria.

Clean energy transition names and utilities are \(+7\%\) more expensive on \(+0.7pp\) better growth CAGR (see Exhibit 18). We reiterate our view that overall the utility sector is relatively cheap in our themes, ideas and feedback: sector momentum has turned strategy update in March 2025. While it is not our role to comment on the relative cheapness (or otherwise) of the clean energy transition index (or wider equities), one could argue that our European renewables coverage is looking attractive (much stronger growth at lower multiples).

However, this is skewed by smaller names (Greenergy with \(>30\%\) EBITDA growth in the next two years and Solaria with \(>10\%\) ). Also, when looking at individual relative valuations, we find EDPR and Acciona Energia to be expensive compared to history and, more importantly, to the sector or clean energy transition names today.

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 20) to plot our own estimate of net operational assets and pipeline values (blue bars) as a share of our PO (rebased to 100 at the red dotted line) and against current share price (red dots). Taking Acciona Energia, our PO is mostly composed of operational assets (big dark blue bar) and implies that the market overestimates said operational value and/or pipeline valuation and/or underestimates liabilities (where we believe we have a more conservative and granular view than consensus which does not limit our scope to net financial debt). This supports our Underperform rating on Acciona Energia and even more so on EDPR.

It also supports our Buy rating on ERG given the market valuation is lower than our valuation of operations and the risk- adjusted pipeline (and with the pipeline the most moderate share of SOTP mixes across our coverage). We are also cognisant that Grenergy has more pipeline risks (and negative value for operations given high debt) but execution has been excellent, in contrast to Solaria (delays and multiple verticals addressed), supporting again our relative ratings (respectively rated Buy and Neutral). We keep Orsted at Underperform, despite screening adequately on under- construction pipeline value as we are concerned about near- term overhang from the equity raises and execution. Bottom line, this screen is but one of several tools we use to inform our recommendations.
Exhibit 20: We think the market overestimates Acciona Energia and EDPR valuations BofA renewables pure-players BofA SOTP valuation mix vs current share price (as % PO).
Source:BofA Global Research estimates Note: Greenery operational value is negative from high capex and debt phasing in the Atacama project

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 21) to plot our coverage based on our EV adjustments (meaning multiples are more expensive compared to Bloomberg's EV bridge) and forecasts (higher than consensus as we fully model pipeline growth). We further plot valuation at our PO.

Greenery remains our top pick (off chart given strong EBITDA growth) and we see decent relative value in ERG, whilst Acciona Energia and EDPR are both looking more expensive. Again, we keep Orsted Underperform, despite screening adequately as we have concerns about the near- term overhang from the equity raise and execution.

Acciona Energia (downgrade to Underperform): Recent outperformance has more to do with flows, we believe, with the company executing equity swaps and shorts being covered. The stock is now looking expensive to us, especially as near- term growth is mediocre, given limited gross capacity additions and lacklustre progress on asset rotation. Parent company Acciona is now holding \(>90\%\) of shares, and a full take- out risk remains (management keep all options open). However, we think it more likely that the controlling family will keep a long- term view and the vehicle listed, especially given recent outperformance. See Lacking Energia Act II report.

EDPR (Underperform): We are cautious on EDPR, where we think growth and capacity additions are constrained by too- high leverage, underestimated by the market. Multiples already look rich for us and, whilst sentiment for renewables has got better, improvement on asset rotation and more clarity on asset growth is needed, in our view. As we have written in the past (see Cannot rewind EDPR report) we still hold the view that a take- out by parent EDP (management keep all options open) is unlikely (too much leverage). See Hyperhydro Syndrome report.

Orsted (Underperform): After several challenging years, Orsted is refocusing its strategy on executing projects under construction and repairing its capital structure (DKK60bn/€8bn rights issue) so that it can maintain a solid investment grade credit rating. The downside of its approach is lower earnings, lower growth and lower dividends. Furthermore, it now faces significantly increased adverse policy risk in the US. We expect it to take a few years for Orsted to shift from being an execution story back to a growth story. We reiterated our Underperform pending more visibility on rights issue execution, and despite valuation looking reasonable, given better risk/reward elsewhere in our coverage. See note: Refinanced but not reassured report.

- ERG (upgrade to Buy): The company's unique proposition of low leverage and higher income presents a 'yieldco' profile that investors should find attractive as European rates come down. In addition, the growth profile is now attractively priced and should benefit from wind resources recovery into 2026 rather that asset growth and/or asset rotation gains. See Dividend-mill report.

- Greenergy (Buy): We continue to favour Greenergy as our top pick. The company is drastically changing scope with the Oasis de Atacama platform, but execution has been excellent so far, and especially relative to the sector. Whilst this project's outsized returns are not expected to be sustained in future ventures, we continue to see accretive delivery on projects beyond that and potential for raised ambitions and expectations to drive the equity story further. See Keep it On and on report.

- Solaria (downgrade to Neutral): After no asset growth in 2024, Solaria is expected to double its solar asset base over the next 12 months, and almost quadruple in the next 18 months. Whilst we think progress has been made on solar, more execution is needed given historical delays and under-delivery. In addition, we think the market has already started to price in a significant datacentre upside, and current valuation offering a binary risk-reward to these levels. See Flying closer to the sun report.

A worst- case scenario has been averted in the US and Al load demand in that region should support renewables deployments and/or value creation. Still, spreads have not expanded so far for European developers, and we do not expect much improvement near term, which will constrain upgrades (withstanding better prices). We also think upgrades are constrained as balance sheet capacity is limited and rely on asset rotations, meaning a tight margin of execution overall.

Given power demand growth expectations and limited power supply availability, the laws of supply and demand would mean that either: (a) higher renewable capacity should be offered, meaning incremental capex to deploy and bigger pipeline value and/or (b) the value of energy should go up, meaning better PPAs for renewables and thus better value creation and/or (c) faster and/or better asset rotations to address demand, as buying opportunities are tactical to accelerate pipeline for developers, and thus again better value creation.

We are conscious load growth has been overestimated historically - and the pace of change in the US given rapid tech investments should sustain momentum. However, timing and quantum is difficult to estimate, BofA's US teams calculates \(2 - 3\%\) electricity growth for the next decade, compared to \(5\%\) in 2023 and 2024, meaning pipeline (and/or prices) could accelerate should load growth surprise positively.

However, we are also conscious of limiting factors from grid availability, permitting and more generally capital competition, as pure players are not the only ones in town (alongside larger utilities and dedicated infrastructure and private equity investors). We also think our coverage of pure- play renewables in Europe has limited balance sheet capacity to address more growth, constraining capex upgrades.

1. Policy headwinds for US renewables seem done now that the US tax bill is signed, but final terms are still expected on safe harbor, which could raise costs to secure the pipeline.  
2. The US market needs a lot more power, and more renewables are needed to bridge the supply gap – but European developers have instead cut ambitions recently.  
3. This is understandable given lower value creation spreads recently for European developers and we do not expect much improvement near-term.  
4. Better spreads should attract more capital and thus more competition.  
5. And European pure-play developers do not have the capacity to invest more, given stretched balance sheets and execution risks on pipeline and asset rotations.

Newsflow has been very volatile on US renewable policies since President Trump's election, and ahead of the US tax bill. An averted worst- case scenario had already been the base case since the end of May, as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act bill introduced to

the US House of Representatives had not fully repealed the IRA benefits for renewable developers. We cautioned investors not to get too carried away at that time, as we were still lacking clear evidence of improving value creation spreads across renewables, and potential final changes to the US tax bill were complex, and volatile, as evidenced by subsequent research from our US colleagues. See links to the relevant research reports below:

- 21 May: EDP & Renovaveis: No IRA repeal, but still limited appeal- 16 June: US Cleantech: ~50% of the 2026-2028 renewables pipeline at risk?- 30 June: US Cleantech Flash: Senate GOP sharpens the knife – countdown to vote begins- 30 June: US Power & Utilities: Senate draft legislation requires in service by YE '27; Excise tax on FEOC components- 01 July: US Power & Utilities: Senate passes reconciliation bill – without excise tax; easing of tax credit timing

In our view, the US tax bill offers enough leeway for developers to be able to add capacity for the next 5 years (with CoDs until mid- 2030) which means deployments can be secured beyond the current Trump administration (with the next US presidential election scheduled for November 2028). We provide more details on solar and wind:

- 100% tax credits available for projects that begin construction within 12 months of enactment (i.e., by mid-2026).- Projects have 4 years from construction start to be placed in service, effectively extending 100% PTC/ITC eligibility through mid-2030.- Projects placed in service by the end of 2027 qualify for full credits even without meeting the construction start deadline.- Base credits remain eligible for bonus adders (e.g., domestic content, energy community), which can significantly enhance the final credit value.- Tax credit transferability remains in place for the full duration of the credit lifecycle.

Whilst tax credits are available beyond the mid- 2030s for storage, the US supply chain is more challenged from equipment sourcing rules, given China's dominance in the lithium iron phosphate battery supply chain (a recent study by a German researcher outlined that 98% of active materials are produced by China7). We give more detail on the storage and the supply chain:

- Energy storage and other power projects qualify for full technology-neutral tax credits if construction begins by the end of 2033. Phase-out schedule: 100% in 2033; 75% in 2034, 50% in 2035, and 0% in 2036.- Equipment Sourcing Rule starting in January 2026 (not applicable to anything starting construction by end of 2025). 40% of equipment value must come from non-FEOC (Foreign Entity of Concern) sources, increasing by 5% annually to reach 60%. This is not applicable to anything starting construction by end of 2025 – with safeguards through 2029.
- FEOC taxpayer restrictions on the ability to claim tax credits starting in January 2026, with influenced entity defined as 25% ownerships.
The environment here remains highly volatile, with export restrictions and/or tariffs on minerals and battery technologies from China.

Following the US tax bill signed on 4 July, President Trump signed an executive order on 7 July to issue new and revised guidance on safe harbors, calling into question a widely held belief that 5% capex spent or secured would qualify as having 'begun construction'.

Our US team (see report: US Power & Utilities: Clean energy executive order adds uncertainty on safe harboring: permits) as well as most market participant had assumes it will be challenging to retroactively change projects already safe harbored (including procurement planned within a 12- month window from passage of the US tax bill) and with enough precedent for new projects to keep safe harbouring without much incremental cost. The US Treasury issue guidance on 15 August (see report: US Cleantech Flash: Treasury guidance sparks physical work test report) offering further respite to sentiment (which has already improved). We note the following from developers on Q2 earnings calls (ahead of US Treasury guidance):

- NextEra (the largest US renewable developer): "although there is more certainty with the passage of the bill, we will need to manage that against a backdrop of executive orders, agency rulemakings, tariffs and trade actions."

- Engie (which had a strong pipeline of US projects, in particular for storage): "there remains one uncertainty, which has been well commented, about what we can call start of construction. We're awaiting clarification on August 21 on this. The current definition, which exists today, is obviously a low threshold, so there is definitely room for us, for this threshold to be worsened".

- EDPR (with over 45% of pipeline in North America) on the 5% capex: "the precedent for many, many years" and"if there is any change to that, then we need to see what the cost of additional safe harboring is and then take a position".

- BofA's US Utilities team subsequently hosted an important private developer of US renewables (see US Cleantech: Developer views on treasury guidance & its implications report) with a discussion that highlighted that minor tweaks were consistent with historic standards on safe harbor, and overall Treasury rules less restrictive than feared, with the bigger overhang now shifting to FEOC compliance, especially for storage.

From 2006 through to the early 2020s, there was little to no electric demand growth in the US, and the average pace of electricity demand growth was 0.3%. This changed from 2022 due to greater domestic electrification, industrial reshoring, and datacentre development, leading to a 4.8% national increase in demand for 2023- 2024 - the highest recorded in the past 10 years (see Exhibit 24 and Exhibit 25).
Exhibit 24: Significant rise in power demand in 2023-24 Annual power demand increases for the US (%)
Source: EIA, BofA Global Research
Exhibit 25: Incremental power demand from 2022 US Annual power demand increases 2016-2022 (%)
Source: EIA, BofA Global Research

One of the most notable drivers of this power demand growth is computing and the energy consumption of datacentre servers, which has been a thematic tailwind and debate for the sector for more than a year, as we highlighted in our AI datacentre seeking connections note of April 2024. The reference case of the Energy Information Administration projects electricity consumed for commercial computing will increase faster than any other end use in buildings, from an estimated \(8\%\) of commercial sector electricity consumption in 2024 to \(20\%\) by 2050 (see Exhibit 26). Ultimately, more electricity could be consumed by computing than for any other end- use in the commercial sector, including lighting, space cooling and ventilation (see Exhibit 26). This also takes into account that commercial computing growth will outpace computing efficiency improvements.
Exhibit 26: Electricity use for commercial computing could surpass space cooling, ventilation Electricity consumption in US commercial sector (bn KWh)
Data source: U.S. Energy Information Administration, Annual Energy Outlook 2025 Reference case Data values: Commercial Sector Key Indicators and Consumption
The magnitude and duration of computing load growth theme is however hard to accurately quantify - as is the overload growth for the rest of the decade. Short term,

the US government-owned Energy Information Administration expects short-term growth of \(1.7\%\) in 2025 and \(2026^{8}\) . Longer term, BofA's US industrial team sees \(2.8\%\) electrical demand CAGR over 2023- 30 (see report: removing "grid" lock 3.0) but studies vary across governmental agencies, consultancies, and utilities as to how much power, and how early, is needed.
However, supply can be used to forecast demand as electricity cannot be stored at grid scale, supply must equal demand in real time to avoid outages.

Our US colleagues (see report: electricity demand growth) estimate just over 100GW of accredited capacity (on data sourced from US governmental agencies and regional transmission operators), which would support average nationwide demand growth of \(2.1\%\) per year over the next decade within a range of \(1.5\%\) to \(2.6\%\) .

We also note stronger load growth in regions that have been targeted historically by European developers (for reference, EDPR main US markets are California, Illinois, Indiana and Texas at \(10 - 15\%\) of US capacity each).

A key question that is a frequent source of debate concerns the source of supply for this incremental demand. This can come from new build (gas or renewables), up- rates, optimisation of the existing fleet, delayed retirements, or the return of mothballed facilities. Our US team's supply growth forecast of \(2.1\%\) takes this all into consideration.

On headlines, the Trump administration's 'National Energy Emergency' goal to create affordable, abundant energy is in conflict with the incremental load demand and downshift in some renewable power plans, meaning traditional power generation has geared up, and natural gas power is enjoying increased demand in particular.

However, construction time for new gas capacity is significant (2- 3y at the fastest) and even more so for long- dated new nuclear, meaning renewables are needed to bridge the gap in the short to medium term (solar having as short as a 1- 2y build time). Short term, the Energy Information Administration expects only solar (and storage) to meaningfully contribute in new power generation capacity with \(+55GW\) from utility- scale solar between 2024 and 2026, \(+35GW\) from storage, \(+20GW\) from wind or small- scale solar but no addition from natural gas and still - 20GW from coal closures, retirements or decommissions (see Exhibit 28).
U.S. electric generating capacity (2020-2026) change since 2020, gigawatts
Data source: U.S. Energy Information Administration, Short-Term Energy Outlook, May 2025 Data values: U.S. Electric Generating Capacity

Whilst it is not the subject of this report to go into detail about why the world is building renewables (on top of datacentres load), it is still helpful to give some context. The UN summarises that: "the sustainable energy transition is a transformative shift in how energy is produced, distributed and consumed, aiming to move away from fossil fuels towards a system centred on renewable energy sources. This energy transition is critical to tackling the climate crisis, as fossil fuels still provide 80 percent of global energy supply" and that "accelerating the energy transition requires scaling up renewable energy production and energy storage". With this in mind, one could easily assume that the world will be building more and more renewables every year, and indeed it is.

Between 2020 and 2024, the US has increased renewables deployments from 35GW to 56GW (see Exhibit 29) and European countries from 33GW to 80GW (see Exhibit 30). We purposely focus on these two geographies as the main source of growth across our coverage. US renewable deployments are set to accelerate still from 56GW in 2024 to close to 79GW by 2030 (see Exhibit 29). At the same time, Europe's deployments are expected to stabilize from 80GW in 2024 to around 85- 95GW until the end of the decade (see Exhibit 30).
Exhibit 29: US solar was expected to ramp up ahead of the US tax bill US solar PV and onshore wind additions (MW) - before the US tax bill
Exhibit 30: Europe renewable growth more paced Europe solar PV and onshore wind additions (MW)

Like many new technologies, the adoption of renewables has been underestimated in the past. 10 years ago, the IEA expected over 2,000TWh of global electricity to be generated from renewable resources (excluding hydropower) in 2025, compared to over 4,000TWh in its latest forecasts, undershooting actuals by more than \(50\%\) . Shorter term, we note European and US additions in 2023- 24 beat BNEF forecasts from 2022 by 40- 50%. As such, we could expect current forecasts to still be conservative.

However, we also note some more recent uncertainty. Recent BNEF revisions have curbed European solar PV in the near term, whilst the ramp- up in European wind additions is uncertain given forecasts have overshot actuals more recently. More importantly, we believe some caution is warranted in the US (as discussed in the previous section on recent US policy changes) as BNEF forecasts do not assume major disruptions from import tariffs, and assume ongoing tax credits.

Despite the secular thematic tailwind of the energy transition and electrification trends, many renewable developers across our coverage, from large integrated utilities to pureplay operators, have cut growth ambitions in recent years:

Iberdrola was the first to shift capital allocation, from \(- 50\%\) renewables in its 2020 CMD plan to \(- 60\%\) grids in its 2022 update. Enel followed suit, from \(- 50\%\) renewables in its 2022 CMD plan to \(- 35\%\) in its 2023 update. Another large investor, RWE, had ambitions to deploy €55bn in clean technologies in its 2023 CMD plan, which were revised \(- 25\%\) lower in late 2024. Pure players have walked away from ambitious capacity additions, with EDPR deciding to cut 2023- 26 capex by \(15\%\) in early 2024, and again from 6GW in 2025- 26 to 3.5GW in early 2025. Meanwhile, Acciona Energia lowered medium- term growth from 1.8- 2.0GW to 1.25- 1.50GW in early 2024 with its new asset rotation program further reducing net capex deployment. However, not all utilities are meaningfully cutting ambitions. Indeed, Engie's 3y capex plan still foresees \(50 - 65\%\) of investments in renewables as of early 2025 (from over \(55 - 65\%\) in its 2023 CMD plan).
We would argue that this shift was in part due to relative returns improving for networks (more capex with improving regulation) compared to renewables, as we discuss in the following section.

We still see a lack of clear evidence of improving value creation spreads in renewables. Indeed, we would argue that: (a) capex is not really improving, (b) prices are not really improving and (c) cost of capital is not really improving - meaning returns and value creation spreads are not really improving neither. This does not support higher capex for renewables for now.

To support this argument, we have built a value creation spread historical model for renewables in the US and Europe, showcasing the impact of changes in (a) capex, (b) prices via PPA levels and (c) cost of capital via rates. We are cognizant that our model is somehow illustrative, as it is simplified and only these variables are changing. (We could for instance change our assumptions on capex efficiencies from better load factors and/or lower deterioration, on forward power curves alongside periods, or on equity risk premium associated with our cost of capital estimates.)

Value creation spreads have improved slightly in the US over the past two years, but have deteriorated in Europe, with the main difference being the improvement in PPA prices and inflationary tax credits in the US on a \(\) base\(see Exhibit 31).

However, for a European developer portfolio, we think this means overall spread compression (see Exhibit 32), as the US exposure was \(50\%\) at best for the most exposed, and any need for rapid geographical rebalancing cannot be easily done given long- term planning and supply commitment.
Exhibit 31: We think that value creation spreads have compressed in
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, BNEF, LevelTen
Exhibit 32: However, for a European developer portfolio we think this means overall spread compression
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, BNEF, LevelTen

Near- term improvements are difficult to call, particularly on the capex front. Pricing risks from negative hours and curtailment could lower PPA prices, alongside limited support from forward curves in Europe - but the US seems to already benefit from power supply- demand imbalances (whilst the 'datacentre premium' seems to remain elusive in Europe), which should increase spreads in the near term, if sustained. Lower rates in Europe should mechanically improve spreads, but this could be reflected in lower PPAs (as a function of capex and cost of capital) and rates in the US are expected to be stable, despite recent headlines from President Trump to drive lower Fed rates.

For wind, turbine prices (50- 75% of wind capital costs) rose \(+30\%\) between June 2020 and June 2024 (see Exhibit 33) but have remained stable since, and European manufacturers are not expected to chase price competition (see the reports, Nordex Q1 2025 review, Siemens Energy Q2 2025 review and Vestas Q1 2025 review, with commentary on cost/tariffs/margin pressure).

Investors continue to debate whether Chinese turbines could further penetrate European markets (only a few projects have used Chinese OEMs so far), given supportive commentary from developers and industry experts on quality being broadly equivalent to European manufacturers and therefore improved economics for project developers.

However, our conversations with renewable management teams and industry leaders indicate some reluctance to use Chinese turbines at home and/or in core markets, which could be the result of soft power pressures at the European Union level (on strengthening local competitiveness as part of the Green Deal Industrial Plan). We note that projects are still being presented with Chinese turbines, including, for instance,

Kincardine (a 50MW floating offshore wind farm project in the UK near Scotland), but political headwinds remain (given calls to lock Chinese companies out of critical national infrastructure, as has already happened at the Sizewell nuclear project in the UK).

For solar, module prices ( \(\sim 30 - 40\%\) of solar capital costs) decreased \(- 50\%\) between June 2020 and June 2024 and by a further \(- 10\%\) since (See Exhibit 34). While US tariffs have been in place for some time on Chinese solar, further US tariffs on Southeast Asian countries could see Europe become a dumping ground for unsold modules, panels and/or trackers, while the US continues to ramp up local manufacturing. This could support capex for European solar developers. However, potential consolidation and price controls in China (given the very low margin for domestic producers) is an offsetting upside risk for prices in the medium term. Near- term trends are mixed on prices and the supply/demand equilibrium (see the report, Solar China Q1 2025 review).
Exhibit 33: Wind capex has steadily risen in recent years but stabilised more recently Wind Turbine Price Index (S/W)
Exhibit 34: Solar capex has steadily declined in recent years but more stable recently Solar Standard Monocrystalline Module Price (S/W)

We maintained a prudent view on PPA levels in our recent PPA reality check into Q2 report, with data suggesting European PPA levels are still declining ( \(- 4\%\) yoy) and we would argue that power forwards offer no gap and therefore no support for pricing to improve in the near term. European PPA levels are also restarted declining sequentially in 2Q25 ( \(- 3\%\) qoq) after stabilizing in 1Q25 quarter ( \(+1\%\) qoq) and against steady declines since the 1Q23 peak. Again, this is unsupportive (see Exhibit 35).

Exhibit 35: European PPA levels are stable but we would argue that power forwards offer no gap and therefore no support for pricing to improve in the near term European average forwards versus LevelTen Europe PPA levels, 1Q21- 2Q25 (€/MWh)

Conversely, US levels there are growing again (+6% qoq) after hitting a pause last quarter. We had flagged this pause as counterintuitive (see our earlier PPA Q1 report) with higher prices likely underpinned by strong load growth expectations despite a volatile political and regulatory context. This could be supportive for US renewable deployments, but we would also note that US PPA are down in € terms, which we could argue is more important for our coverage of Europe developers.

We also see risks in value creation spreads from price uncertainty as negative and/or low- value power hours are increasingly more frequent in Europe. This would translate into lower expected PPA prices, as offtakers can secure energy at potentially lower prices in spot markets. Indeed, spot prices can be much lower than offered PPA prices during the day (as low- cost hours are usually during peak production, which usually happens at mid- day because of solar production).

Exhibit 40: There is already \(20\%\) more low-price hours so far in 2025 vs 2024 and \(800\%\) more than in 2019, 2021 or 2022 (but -7% less than in 2020 Cumulative number of hours below €10/€10 in European markets
Source:BofAGlobal Research estimates,Datastream,ENTSO-E Note:Europe is average of France,Germany,Great-Britain,Italy,Nordics (Nordpool) and Spain

Not all markets are equal. Low- price hours are more frequent in the Nordics (high capacity in hydro and wind generation), yet almost non- existent in Italy (see Exhibit 41). Note also a different starting point, with absolute power prices in the Nordics 50- 75% lower than in Italy in the last 3, 5 or 10 years.

Exceptional hydro and wind resources in Europe over the last two years are complicating the picture for underlying changes - but we would nonetheless argue that low- price hours should be structurally more frequent in European power markets, unless demand picks up and/or more flexibility is introduced in each system (with higher grid investments, but also supportive regulation, notably for batteries).
Exhibit 41: Low-price hours are more frequent in the Nordics, yet almost non-existent in Italy Cumulative number of hours below €10/€10 in European markets, 2023-2025 ytd
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Datastream, ENTSO-E

We also note more frequent commentary from corporates on grid curtailments for renewables generation, given constrained networks. Whilst granular and aggregated data are more difficult to obtain (and compile), we highlight the European Commission's work on redispatch and congestion management from \(2024^{9}\) showing that redispatch volumes in all investigated grid- expansion scenarios increase massively from \(60bn\) in 2040 in a median scenario (see Exhibit 42) with half to a third coming from market congestion rather than grid congestion (see Exhibit 43). Most European markets offer compensation for technical curtailment, meaning economics are fine for now (with a small \(0 / 0\) discount). We do highlight Spain is not offering compensation when technical curtailments are reported one day in advance.

Given substantial amounts of renewable generation to be curtailed, we think there is a risk on future value creation spreads, as effective load factors should compress and offsetkers could use this as an opportunity to negotiate lower prices from lower guarantee of availability (as green energy hourly matching is expected to grow more prevalent, as technology, availability and awareness improves).
Exhibit 42: Redispatch volumes in all investigated grid-expansion scenarios to increase massively Evolution of redispatch volumes and costs in the European power system, 2022, 2030 and 2040
Source: European Commission Note: NGE = extreme-grid-expansion, AGE = ambitious-grid-expansion, BAU = business-as-usual

Exhibit 43: Substantial amounts of renewable generation should be curtailed Curtailment of variable renewable generation. Differentiated based on whether curtailment occurred in the market, or due to grid congestion, 2030 and 2040.
Source: European Commission Note: NGE = extreme-grid-expansion, AGE = ambitious-grid-expansion, BAU = business-as-usual

Though not the focus of this report, we remind investors that rates have not much improved over the last 2- 3 years either. BofA is expecting the US 10yr to remain around the current \(4.5\%\) level across 2026 (see report: BofA latest economic forecasts) which will not support US developments, but German yields are expected to drop from the current \(2.7\%\) to \(2\%\) near term and across 2026, which could support spreads for European developments overall. Lastly, whilst BofA Global Research's internally calculated equity risk premium does show moderation over the last 3- 5 years, the output is stable over the last 1.5- 2 years, and thus not supportive for value creation spreads (see Exhibit 45).

US power prices have gone up, but PPA levels have followed

Power prices in the US have gone up by 50% or \(\) 30\(since 2020 (when considering power forwards) and could rise +25% further before the end of the decade (our US team recently hosted an expert call following the US tax bill, see OB3 = higher electricity prices, lower renewable development report) - (see Exhibit 46).

However, PPA levels have matched this increase, and are up even more by 115% or \(\) 35\(since 2020, also reflecting capex (wind turbines prices have gone up, solar has seen import tariffs) and cost of capital (rates have gone up) increases (see Exhibit 47).
Exhibit 46: US power forwards have gone up 50% since 2020 Selected US power zones year ahead forward, Jul 2015- Jul 2025 (S/MWh)
There is a complex US power equation to solve
The final impact of the US tax bill, and volatile US energy and renewables policies, are still unclear, as we think there are multiple angles and contradicting intentions.
Exhibit 47: US PPA levels have followed US power forwards, LevelTen US PPA levels (S/MWh) excluding PTC, 2Q20- 2Q25

Holistically, the US needs more power, but does not want to pay too much for it, and is not necessarily facilitating supply of new renewables – therefore, prices likely need to go up to attract more capital. And, whilst PPA prices have indeed increased, they have not done so sufficiently to see developers piling up new projects.
Summary of contradicting arguments on US power and renewables

Trump administration wants lower US energy bills... but US tax bill might result in higher wholesale prices Trump administration and tech players want to lead in AL... but power supply is lacking US needs more power... but only renewables can be rapidly built US needs more renewables... but capex might increase (tariffs) and rates are high Value creation needs to improve... but PPA levels are already rising Deployments need to accelerate... but developers have re-sized ambitions Prices need to go further up... but Trump administration wants lower US energy bills
Source: BofA Global Research
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

However, with more clarity on full tax credit details now given (excepting for FOEC rules which could impact storage projects more specifically), we could see an initial burst of activity as developers rush to qualify projects, given the expected accelerated phase- out of tax credits that will reduce the number of viable projects over the longer term. As reduced support for renewables and the long lead time for energy resources like natural gas and nuclear will limit the ability of generation to keep pace with load growth, prices will mechanically have to increase (assuming the laws of supply and demand). We also note that US retail power bills have already seen up to \(20\%\) increases in some regions in the past year. More retail power bill inflation from datacentre load could cause politicians and regulators to re- evaluate their support of Al (see note: US utility bills: where electric bills may become problematic report) but could equally cause a re- evaluation of renewables policies.

Load growth from the Al/datacentre upside (as well as wider electrification trends) is also being captured by 'traditional' power sources, from nuclear deals (from the landmark 1GW Talen- Amazon \(^{10}\) 2024 deal) to even bigger hydro deals (3GW Brookfield- Google \(^{11}\) 2025 deal) or dedicated power land with gas deals (190MW Calpine- CyrusOne \(^{12}\) 2025 deal). Time to market remains of the essence for tech players looking to capture an edge in artificial intelligence ahead of competition.

Private players (landmark 10.5GW Brookfield- Microsoft \(^{13}\) 2024 deal) are also taking a big chunk of load growth. This could imply a lack of scale and/or scope from 'smaller' public pure players, and private operators or equity perhaps able to deploy capital more rapidly to meet the tech industry demand.

However, this could arguably also support pipeline or asset rotations from said 'smaller' pure players and, given pipeline size is usually a multiple of expected capacity additions, similar deals could be signed by European renewable pure players and/or larger integrated firms in one form or another.
We also refer back to our note: European PPA outlook with Pexapark expert call in 2024, where we discussed that the 'low- hanging' fruit for renewables had already been

addressed, as the 'sophisticated' offtakers market was quickly filled. This means energy sales (in the form of PPAs) need to now guarantee \(24x7\) green energy for the wider market. Whilst this was a comment relating more specifically to the overall PPA market in Europe, it does apply in our view to the overall dynamic seen in power markets.

Tech players have been the main offtakers for renewables power in the US and in Europe, with strong historically energy transition commitment, and increasingly more pledges to ensure clean electricity purchases are hourly matched with their consumption, this was usually done by investment in renewable projects or offtake agreements.

However, we noted a shift in 2024, with similar takeaways from our US team Global Energy 2025 Forum (see note) as again, time to market is of the essence for tech players and datacentres need speed, reliability, and clean energy (in that order). However, clean energy should not come at the expense of speed and reliability.

Our conversations with industry stakeholders and corporates also indicate that there is a growing sophistication exercise in PPA structuration, which is more easily achieved by wider and larger integrated firms than 'smaller' pure players, as they are more able to sufficiently deploy capital and aggregate production, meaning disintermediation risks. Conversely, this could again support asset rotations and/or pipeline acceleration. We would also argue that wider integrated firms prefer to allocate more capex into regulated networks, and committed capital with a regulator cannot switch back into renewables easily.

We have detailed in a previous section of this report how larger integrated utilities had shifted capital allocation towards regulated networks over the last years, in part due to relative returns improving for networks (more capex with improving regulation) compared to renewables (declining spreads for European developers). We also noted that renewable pure players had reduced ambitions over the last years, which we would argue is not only due to tighter value creation spreads, but also constrained balance sheets.

Focusing on larger renewable pure players under our coverage (we exclude smaller names such as Grenergy and Solaria for comparability on scale) we expect a significant drop in net capacity growth in the coming years, as gross ambitions have been revised down whilst asset rotation programs have been maintained or raised. This means net capacity growth is dropping from \(13\%\) on average in the last 5 years to \(5.5\%\) in the next 3 years (see Exhibit 49). Commensurably, leverage (defined as net debt including leases to reported EBITDA including capital gains) doubled from \(2x\) on average in 2022 to \(4x\) in 2024, but should step down to \(3x\) by 2026 (see Exhibit 50) as net capacity growth slows. However, this leverage reduction is somehow conditioned by asset rotations.
Exhibit 49: Ambitions have been cut for renewable pure players Net GW capacity growth in renewables (%)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 50: Leverage has doubled, but now reducing Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA excluding capital gains
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

Renewable developers can work through 2 levers to control leverage. They can either build fewer assets (lower gross additions) or sell more (higher asset rotation) or a combination thereof. Over the last few years, gross additions ambitions have been revised down. Close to its 2021 IPO, Acciona Energia was targeting slightly less than 2GW of gross additions in 2025, without depending on farm-downs/asset rotation for funding. However, it is now expecting 0.6GW of gross additions for 2025 and is completing a €3bn asset rotation program over 2024- 25. Similarly, and more recently at its 2023 CMD, EDPR was guiding to 4.25GW of gross additions and 1.25GW of asset rotations on average. As of today it is expecting 2GW of gross additions with €2bn of asset rotations in 2025 alone.

We think this deleveraging strategy is not without risks. Acciona Energia and EDPR have now both execution risks over 2 pipelines (gross additions and asset rotations) compared to ERG (no asset rotation program, more limited gross additions). Any misstep or phasing could impact leverage ratios, as impacting net debt from spending or proceeds, but also reported EBITDA as benefitting from asset rotation gains.

Source: BofA Global Research estimates
Exhibit 52: ... meaning also a big part of EBITDA Reported EBITDA and capital gains as % of total (€m)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates

We also think underlying leverage is much higher than headlines figuresIndeed, we have repeatedly argued in our research that underlying leverage for renewable developers continue to be much higher than headline figures suggest. We continue to argue that net debt is understated notably given capex payables, tax equity liabilities in the US, whilst EBITDA benefits from tax credits and asset rotations. We do agree that there are some unfavourable factors as well, as operating assets do not contribute for the entire year (with a CoD likely towards year- end). We could, however, also question if capex is fully paid, given high property, plant and equipment payables and therefore capex being financed by working capital rather than debt. Across our coverage, we estimate economic leverage 1- 3x higher than reported (see Exhibit 53)
Exhibit 53: Underlying leverage 1-3x higher than reported in 2025E IFRS leverage vs BofA economic adjustments (x)

Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA including capital gains Note: Economic liabilities including mainly tax equity, PPE payables, provisions BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Exhibit 54: Stubbornly higher for EDPR at \(7.5x+\) vs ANE and ERG dropping towards 3.5-4x and Orsted at 2.5-3.5x in 2025-27E BofA economic leverage (x)

Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Net debt including leases/reported EBITDA including capital gains Note: Economic liabilities including mainly tax equity, PPE payables, provisions BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

EDPR management reports net debt as net financial debt (we estimate 4.5x in 2025, see Exhibit 55, 56 and 57) excluding IFRS adjustments, which would add \(>0.5x\) to leverage. More importantly, net debt excludes tax equity liabilities, while EBITDA benefits from tax credit income. Adjusting leverage for tax credits at the EBITDA level or for tax equity at the net debt level would add \(1.5 - 2x\) to reported or IFRS leverage. We also think there are \(>1.5x\) underlying adjustments from PPE working capital (property, plant and equipment payables \(=\) capex debt) and provisions and excluding capital gains from asset rotations. This would bring economic leverage to 8.4x. However, adjusting for 2025 assets not yet contributing \(100\%\) to EBITDA (given capacity phasing during the year), we estimate underlying economic leverage at EDPR would reach \(- 8x\) (and \(- 7.5x\) without taking US liabilities into account).

Nevertheless, renewable pure- play developers do have some flexibility to control leverage. We show below the sensitivity of EDPR's leverage (on a reported basis, using reported net debt ex IFRS and reported EBITDA including capital gains) to different scenarios to 2030. We also commensurably recalculate the EBITDA growth rate. We model from 2027, given 2025 and 2026 deployments are close to fully secured (see Exhibit 58).

Assuming 500GW less/more gross deployment than in our base case (at 1.3GW in 2026 and 2GW from 2027) EDPR could shift leverage by \(+ / - 0.3x\) by 2030E. However, this would mean that growth would drop/increase by \(+ / - 20\%\) from \(6.5\%\) in our base case (see Exhibit 59).
In addition, to reinforce our earlier argument that leverage is at risk over two pipelines (gross deployments and asset rotations), we show that EDPR's leverage would be more impacted by
a lack of asset rotation than by higher gross deployments (similar EBITDA growth but no gains, thus higher reported leverage, and lower debt reduction).
Exhibit 58:EDPR can accelerate de-leveraging... EDPR reported net debt / EBITDA sensitivity to different scenarios
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 59: ... at the cost of growth EDPR reported EBITDA growth sensitivity to different scenarios
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
EDPR is considering selling minority stakes to soften reported leverage, with lower net debt while still benefitting from consolidating \(100\%\) of the EBITDA.

Management reiterated this intention at the Q2 2025 call. EDPR associates and minorities had broadly similar book values as of 2024 (€1.2bn vs €1.3bn) which meant limited adjustment needed for economic leverage for now. We also note that this would raise minorities at the net income level for both companies, and could therefore constrain share price performance, especially at the EDP level.

Indeed, we do need to acknowledge that EDPR does not issue debt directly (meaning no flexibility from hybrids for instance). Debt is instead raised at the parent EDP level, whose credit profile - while broadly stable - has 'narrow ratings headroom', as per our Credit colleagues (see their report, EDP Q1 2025 credit review). While they think the detailed calculation of credit hurdles is complicated by numerous adjustments at the EBITDA, FFO and net debt levels, we also do not see much headroom for EDP's FFO/net debt ratio around the \(20\%\) , a level at which rating agencies have indicated they would look at downgrading debt ratings (Exhibit 61). EDP reiterated its commitment to a 'strong BBB' credit rating, but plans to provide more granular guidance at the November CMD.

Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

With all the above in mind, we find it useful to explore the catch- 22 problem faced by renewables developers, where capital is spent upfront of EBITDA contributions. As we have analysed in our EDP/EDPR Hyperhydro Syndrome report, growth can accelerate and become more compelling - but credit ratings have very tight headroom, meaning execution needs to be near- perfect, with any delays or funding gap (from delays or lower tax equity funding or capex financing for instance) growing as the pipeline itself grows.
Bottom line, renewables developers had bigger ambitions even only a couple quarters ago (EDPR management had previous ambitions of \(>4GW\) per annum back in 2023, compared to \(

Batteries that can 'plug' the growth gapBatteries are the missing ingredient of the renewables 'recipe', as we introduced in our report: recharging the appetite for renewables. Indeed, the intermittent nature of renewable generation means storage (via batteries) is needed not only to smooth loads, but also to address merchant monetization. Daily power spreads have already widened 2x since the Ukraine war, offering arbitrage opportunities for batteries. Ancillary grid services are also valuable (and are needed to strengthen networks) and we expect regulation to be introduced in more countries. Costs are also coming down, with turnkey system quotes halving in 2024. This all means potentially better IRRs than conventional renewables, with improving returns and faster deployments.

We see this trend ongoing, with deployments accelerating in Europe (from 20GWh per annum in 2024 to 85GWh in 2030E, see Exhibit 66) and in the US (from 30GWh to 70GWh across the same period, see Exhibit 67), albeit with a near- term pause given uncertainty on policy and the supply chain from tariffs. Across our coverage, capex is increasingly shifting to storage across the board.

Our PO for Acciona Energia is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €17.5.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7 - 8\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and medium- term asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(50\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).

For our EV/EBITDA, we use a \(8x2026Y + 1\) target multiple (vs \(8.5xY + 1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia.

Upside/downside to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for EDPR is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €7.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6 - 6.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.2x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables.

Upside/downside to our PO are wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for ERG is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based), a group EV/EBITDA multiple, and a DDM, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables (with a DDM added given ERG 'yieldco' profile). Our resulting PO is €23.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with 6.5- 7.5% WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and no asset rotation gains. We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by - 13% and beyond by - 38% (half the base discount used across our renewable coverage given lower relative growth ambitions).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 9x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs 8.8x Y+1 median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables but a de- risked profile more specifically for ERG.
For our DDM, we use 8.5% CoE with terminal 80% payout and 3.5% growth.

Upside/downside risks to our PO are: wind load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector - as well as dividend or share buy- backs more specifically for ERG.
Our PO for Solaria is derived from a SOTP (DCF- based), an approach that we think reflects the underlying value creation potential and associated execution risks. Our resulting PO is €79.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with 7.5- 8.5% WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of 30% (over 30% of the pipeline). We discounted growth to 2030 by - 35% and beyond by - 85% (slightly higher medium- term than our - 25% and - 75% base case). We have separately modelled the Oasis Atacama project with no further sell down.

Upside/downside risks to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables Capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our DKK255 PO (ADR of \(13.21 for Orsted is based on a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) valuation that values Orsted's existing and future wind development projects using a discounted cash flow (DCF) methodology. We use a 7.6% weighted- average cost of capital (WACC) assumption.

Upside risks to our price objective are a de- escalation of US clean energy policy risk, lower bond yields, stronger GBP, higher inflation and lower costs/capex trends. Additional upside risks are new projects being won at high implied returns and sale of
existing projects at high valuations.

Downside risks to our price objective are higher bond yields, weaker GBP, lower inflation and higher costs/capex trends and project cancellations, delays or impairments. Additional downside risks are increased competition at offshore wind auctions, changes in regulation for existing assets and lower prices / delays in asset sales.
Our PO for Solaria is derived from a SOTP (DCF- based), an approach that we think reflects the underlying value creation potential and associated execution risks. Our resulting PO is €15.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6.5 - 7.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads (on capex - 30% lower than sector), and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by - \(35\%\) and beyond by - \(85\%\) (higher than our 25- 75 base discounts given execution risks). We also price in €600m of datacentre upside.

Upside/downside risks to our PO are: solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.
